variants.Description in input context: c.248G>A (p.G83D) - This variant causes a structural change in the protein, affecting its function.
c.257C>T (p.Y86*)- This variant introduces a premature stop codon, leading to a truncated protein.

Material used.Description: The experiment was conducted using the HEK293 cell line.

Readout description.Result Description: Protein expression was reduced by 30% for the variant NM_001126112.3:c.248G>A compared to wild-type control. The protein exhibited altered mobility on the gel, suggesting a structural change.

No protein band was detected for the variant NM_001126112.3:c.257C>T, indicating complete loss of function.  A slightly smaller band was occasionally visible, potentially representing degradation products.

Biological replicates.Description: Three independent transfections with each construct were performed.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate on the western blot.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type cDNA was used as a positive control, showing normal protein expression and mobility.

Basic negative control.Description: Empty vector control showed no detectable protein band.

Validation controls P/LP.Description: Two previously validated pathogenic TP53 variants (c.156A>G and c.727G>A) were included as positive controls for pathogenicity.

Validation controls B/LB.Description: One known benign TP53 variant (c.1299A>C) was included as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: ANOVA followed by Tukey's post-hoc test was used for statistical analysis of protein band intensities (p < 0.05).

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Protein expression between 80% and 120% of the wild-type control on day 7.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Protein expression outside the 80-120% range of the wild-type control or significant changes in protein mobility.

Approved assay.Description: Western blotting is a standard assay for assessing protein expression and post-translational modifications in TP53 research.
